misconceptions.name: Solving an unrelated physics problem instead of summing even integers
misconceptions.description: The program reads three double values (v0, v1, t) and computes average acceleration instead of reading five integers and summing only the even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment is to read initial velocity, final velocity, and time, then compute and print the average acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly five integers from the user, check each one to see if it is even (using something like n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of the even numbers, and finally print the sum in the required format.
symptoms: Prompt text refers to 'v0, v1, and t' instead of five integers.
Only three inputs are read from the user, not five.
Inputs are stored in double variables rather than integers.
Computation uses the formula (v1 - v0) / t, which is specific to physics acceleration.
No loop is used to process multiple numbers.
No conditional check for even numbers and no accumulator for the sum of evens.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reuse of a template from a different textbook problem (average acceleration) without adapting it to the current specification, indicating weak alignment between the problem statement and the implemented algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Set this code aside and re-read the problem statement. First, write out the algorithm in plain language: repeat 5 times, read an integer, if it is even add it to a running sum, then after the loop print the sum. Only then translate that algorithm into Java with an int sum variable, a for-loop from 1 to 5, and an if (n % 2 == 0) check.
related_concepts: Problem decomposition from English to code
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code (prompt, variable names, formula, and output message) clearly matches a standard average-acceleration exercise and does not implement any part of the required even-number summation.

evidence.note: The prompt refers to v0, v1, and t instead of asking for 5 integers, showing the student is solving a different problem.
The program reads exactly three double values for v0, v1, and t, rather than five integers, and uses no loop to process multiple inputs.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: The core computation and output are for average acceleration, not for summing even numbers, and there is no sum or even-number check.

misconceptions.task: Reading 5 integers from input, Loop structure to process inputs, Conditional check for even numbers (n % 2 == 0), Accumulating sum and printing result
misconceptions.name: Submitted Code for Unrelated Problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code that calculates average acceleration, which is completely unrelated to the assigned problem requiring reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones. This indicates a serious error in matching the code to the assignment requirements, resulting in zero functionality related to the prompt.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code intended for a different assignment, likely one involving kinematic calculations (acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must implement a counting loop (5 iterations), use conditional logic (modulus operator to check for evenness), and employ an accumulator variable initialized to zero to track the required sum.
symptoms: Code prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Code uses floating-point inputs/variables (double) instead of integers.
Calculates 'acceleration' instead of 'sum'.
Missing required control structures (loops, if statements).
misconceptions.root_cause: Misplaced file or severe misreading/misinterpretation of the problem prompt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the problem statement carefully and write new code that specifically implements the required logical flow: read 5 numbers, use a loop, and conditionally add even numbers to a sum variable.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code is unequivocally solving a different problem (average acceleration), as evidenced by the variable names, prompt text, and calculation steps, ensuring 100% confidence in this diagnosis.

evidence.note: The entire functional logic is dedicated to calculating acceleration, not the sum of even numbers as required by the assignment.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Submitted
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code that solves a completely different problem (kinematic acceleration calculation) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). The code reads 3 doubles and calculates acceleration rather than reading 5 integers and summing even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the assignment is to calculate acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time using the formula a = (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers from the user and calculating the sum of only the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Code reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
No loop structure present to process multiple inputs
No even/odd checking logic using modulo operator
Output prints acceleration value instead of sum of even numbers
Input prompt asks for physics variables (v0, v1, t) instead of integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete task mismatch - either wrong file submitted, copy-pasted from different assignment, or fundamental confusion about assignment requirements
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Clarify with student which problem they were supposed to solve. If this was wrong file submission, resubmit correct code. Otherwise, start fresh with: (1) read 5 integers in a loop, (2) check each with n % 2 == 0, (3) accumulate sum of even numbers, (4) print result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence because the submitted code is functionally correct for a physics problem but completely fails to address the assigned problem of summing even numbers. The mismatch is unambiguous and total.

evidence.note: Reads 3 double values for physics variables instead of 5 integers as required

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Calculates and prints acceleration (physics formula) instead of sum of even numbers
Entire program solves physics acceleration problem with no attempt at looping, even-checking, or summing logic required for the assignment

misconceptions.name: Implemented an average-acceleration program instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The submitted program solves a completely different problem: it reads three values v0, v1, and t as doubles, computes (v1 - v0) / t, and prints an "average acceleration" message. It does not attempt to read 5 integers, does not check for even numbers, does not accumulate a sum of evens, and does not print the required result. As a result, none of the rubric criteria for this question are addressed in the code.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that submitting this existing average-acceleration example (reading v0, v1, t and computing (v1 - v0) / t) is acceptable for the task, or they have confused this question with a different one and did not adapt the code to match the current specification.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must be tailored to the given specification: read 5 integers from the user (e.g., using a loop or five separate input calls), check each number with a condition like n % 2 == 0 to determine if it is even, maintain an accumulator that adds only the even numbers, and finally print the sum in the requested format (e.g., "Sum of even numbers: 14").
symptoms: Prompt text asks for "v0, v1, and t" instead of 5 integers
Program reads only three values, not five
Variables are doubles v0, v1, t, not integers representing the 5 inputs
Computation performed is (v1 - v0) / t, unrelated to summing even numbers
Output message describes "The average acceleration" instead of "Sum of even numbers"
misconceptions.root_cause: Most likely the student reused or copied a solution for a different textbook/example problem (average acceleration) and did not re-design the algorithm for this question, or they misread the task and focused on a physics formula instead of the required input-processing-output behavior.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, re-read the problem statement and write down the required steps in plain language: how many inputs, of what type, what condition to check (even numbers), how to accumulate the result, and what output format is expected. Then implement code that directly follows those steps rather than reusing code from an unrelated example.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to code structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All identifiers, formulas, and text output in the submission match a standard average-acceleration example and none of the elements required for summing even numbers appear anywhere in the code.

evidence.note: This block shows the program reading three doubles for v0, v1, t, computing (v1 - v0) / t, and printing an "average acceleration" message, which is unrelated to reading 5 integers and summing the even ones as required.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Problem Implementation (Off-Topic Code)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating average acceleration, which is completely irrelevant to the assigned task of finding the sum of 5 input integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to have either copied code from a different assignment or entirely misunderstood the core goal of the problem, believing they were asked to calculate acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requirement was to read 5 separate integers, check each for evenness, and accumulate the sum of only the even numbers.
symptoms: Code logic is completely unrelated to the problem statement.
Program prompts for 'v0, v1, and t:' instead of just requesting 5 numbers.
Uses floating-point types (double) instead of the required integer types.
misconceptions.root_cause: Major failure in problem comprehension or submission of wrong code artifact.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem prompt carefully. You need to read five numbers and use conditional logic (if statement with the modulus operator) inside a loop to determine and sum the even ones. Do not calculate acceleration.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire code snippet calculates acceleration, which has zero overlap with the problem describing the sum of even numbers.

evidence.note: The prompt asks for physics variables (v0, v1, t) instead of inputting 5 integers.
The core logic calculates acceleration using doubles, violating the requirements to use integers, a loop, conditional checks, and summation for even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type Usage
misconceptions.description: The student used `double` variables (`v0`, `v1`, `t`) and `nextDouble()` to read input, while the problem explicitly requires reading and summing integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student might overlook the distinction between integer and floating-point types for input, or this is simply inherited from the off-topic code they submitted.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires reading integers, necessitating the use of the `int` data type and `input.nextInt()` for reading values.
symptoms: Program reads floating-point numbers instead of integers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Using code tailored for floating-point calculations (acceleration) instead of integer processing (sum of evens).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure you are using `int` data type for integer tasks and the corresponding `nextInt()` scanner method.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The variables are explicitly defined as `double` and the input method is `nextDouble()` (lines 9-12).

evidence.note: Variables are declared as double, but the problem requires integer input.

misconceptions.name: Using double instead of int for integer inputs
misconceptions.description: Student uses nextDouble() and double variables to read input that should be integers. This suggests confusion between integer and floating-point data types.
misconceptions.student_belief: All numeric input should be read as double using nextDouble()
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Integer inputs should be read with nextInt() into int variables. Use nextDouble() and double only for decimal/floating-point values.
symptoms: Code reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
Variables declared as 'double v0, v1, t' instead of integer types
Uses nextDouble() instead of nextInt()
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may not understand the difference between int and double types, or copied code from a different (physics) assignment
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change 'double' to 'int' and change 'nextDouble()' to 'nextInt()' for integer inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses double and nextDouble() when problem requires integers; this is unambiguous.

evidence.note: Uses double and nextDouble() instead of int and nextInt() for reading the input numbers

misconceptions.name: No loop used to process multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: Student hardcodes reading exactly 3 values into separate variables instead of using a loop to read 5 integers. This prevents the program from handling the required 5 inputs.
misconceptions.student_belief: Each input should be read into a separate named variable
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When reading multiple inputs, use a loop (for or while) to iterate and read each value. This is more scalable and efficient.
symptoms: Only 3 input values are read, not 5
Code repeats same input-reading pattern three times rather than looping
No for-loop or while-loop in the program
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may not understand the purpose of loops, or submitted code from a different assignment that only required 3 inputs
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Wrap the input reading in a for-loop: 'for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = input.nextInt(); ... }'
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The absence of any loop structure is unmistakable; the code reads only 3 values instead of the required 5.

evidence.note: No loop; input reading is hardcoded for 3 values only, not a flexible 5-value loop

misconceptions.name: Missing even-number filter logic
misconceptions.description: Student's program contains no conditional check to filter even numbers. No use of modulo operator (%) to test divisibility. This is the core of the required algorithm.
misconceptions.student_belief: All numbers should be processed the same way without filtering
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Use 'if (number % 2 == 0)' to check if a number is even. Only add even numbers to the sum.
symptoms: No if-statement in the code checking for even numbers
No use of modulo operator (%)
Program calculates unrelated formula instead of filtering
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted wrong code (physics problem) that does not require filtering logic
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add: if (number % 2 == 0) { sum += number; } inside the loop
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no conditional at all and calculates a different formula entirely (acceleration).

evidence.note: Instead of filtering even numbers, code calculates acceleration—completely wrong logic

misconceptions.name: No sum accumulator; wrong calculation and output
misconceptions.description: Student's program completely lacks a sum variable to accumulate even numbers. Instead, it calculates an unrelated physics quantity (acceleration) and prints that.
misconceptions.student_belief: Calculate some formula from the input numbers and print the result
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Maintain a sum variable initialized to 0. Inside the loop, add each even number to it. After the loop, print the final sum.
symptoms: No sum variable declared or used
Output is acceleration, not sum of evens
Calculation is (v1 - v0) / t instead of accumulation
Wrong prompt and wrong output message
misconceptions.root_cause: Student appears to have submitted an entirely different program (acceleration calculation from physics)
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Declare 'int sum = 0;' before the loop. Inside loop: 'if (num % 2 == 0) sum += num;'. After loop: 'System.out.println("Sum of even numbers: " + sum);'
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The complete absence of sum logic and presence of wrong formula is unambiguous evidence.

evidence.snippet:

System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);

Wrong prompt; should ask for 5 integers, not physics variables
